name: Juan Gabriel
description:
'''Alberto Aguilera Valadez''' ({{IPA|es|alˈβeɾto aɣiˈleɾa βalaˈðes}}; 7 January 1950 – 28 August 2016), known professionally as '''Juan Gabriel''' ({{IPA|es|ˈxwaŋ ɡaˈβɾjel|pron|Juan Gabriel -es-mx.ogg}}), was a Mexican [[singer-songwriter]]. Colloquially [[Honorific nicknames in popular music|nicknamed]] '''Juanga''' ({{IPA|es|ˈxwaŋɡa|pron}}) and '''El Divo de Juárez''', Juan Gabriel was known for his flamboyant style, which broke norms and standards within the [[Latin music]] industry. Widely regarded as one of the best and most prolific Mexican composers and singers of all time, he is considered a [[pop icon]].

Juan Gabriel is one of the [[List of best-selling Latin music artists|best-selling Latin music artists in history]] and the top-selling Mexican artist of all time, with over 100 million records sold worldwide.{{refn|The figure of 100 million records sold is supported by multiple sources.<ref>{{cite web |last=Hernandez |first=Noel |date=2024 |title="Amor Eterno"—Juan Gabriel (1990) - Added to the National Registry: 2024 |url=https://www.loc.gov/static/programs/national-recording-preservation-board/documents/Amor-Eterno_Hernandez.pdf |website=loc.gov |publisher=[[Library of Congress]] |language=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |date=2016-08-29 |title=Mexicans mourn Juan Gabriel, a singer who captured his country’s soul |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/the_americas/mexicans-mourn-juan-gabriel-a-singer-who-captured-his-countrys-soul/2016/08/29/40ed1348-9e23-4ea5-a78f-a5bafbb32642_story.html |access-date=2025-08-17 |work=The Washington Post |language=en-US |issn=0190-8286}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Corona |first=Sonia |date=2016-08-29 |title=Legendary Mexican showman Juan Gabriel dies of a heart attack |url=https://english.elpais.com/elpais/2016/08/29/inenglish/1472479612_609817.html |access-date=2025-08-17 |website=EL PAÍS English |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Times |first=-Randall Roberts for the Los Angeles |title=Juan Gabriel |url=https://projects.latimes.com/hollywood/star-walk/juan-gabriel/ |access-date=2025-08-17 |website=latimes.com |language=en}}</ref> ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' estimates the figure at 150 million.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Cano |first=Natalia |date=2025-07-11 |title=Juan Gabriel’s Voice Resonates Again With ‘Nunca Había Amado Así,’ a Hidden Jewel in His Repertoire |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/latin/juan-gabriel-nunca-habia-amado-asi-eterno-1236019071/ |access-date=2025-08-17 |website=Billboard |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Cano |first=Natalia |date=2024-07-15 |title=Google Mexico Celebrates Juan Gabriel With Doodle for Billboard’s No. 1 Anniversary |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/latin/google-mexico-celebrates-juan-gabriel-with-doodle-1235731550/ |access-date=2025-08-17 |website=Billboard |language=en-US}}</ref>|group=nb}} His nineteenth studio album, ''[[Recuerdos, Vol. II]]'', is reportedly the [[List of best-selling albums in Mexico|best-selling album of all time in Mexico]], with over eight million copies sold. During his career, Juan Gabriel wrote around 1,800 songs.

Some of his most popular, [[Juan Gabriel discography|signature songs]] include titles such as "Amor eterno", "[[Recuerdos, Vol. II|Querida]]", "[[Recuerdos|Yo no nací para amar]]", "[[Hasta que te conocí]]", "El Noa Noa", "[[No tengo dinero (Juan Gabriel song)|No tengo dinero]]", "[[Abrázame muy fuerte (song)|Abrázame muy fuerte]]", "Te lo pido por favor", "[[Costumbres]]", "En esta primavera", "[[Pero Qué Necesidad|Pero qué necesidad]]", "La Farsante", "[[Debo Hacerlo (song)|Debo Hacerlo]]", "Te sigo amando", "[[Yo No Sé Qué Me Pasó]]", "[[Siempre en Mi Mente|Siempre en mi mente]]", "[[De mí enamórate]]" and "Lo pasado, pasado"; amongst perhaps his most acclaimed songs are "[[Se Me Olvidó Otra Vez|Se me olvidó otra vez]]" and the heartbreaking ballad "[[Así Fue]]", popularized by and sung with [[Isabel Pantoja]] of [[Spain]]. Many of his compositions have been performed by and with other artists. In 2023, he ranked number 172 on [[Rolling Stone's 200 Greatest Singers of All Time|''Rolling Stone''<nowiki/>'s list of the 200 Greatest Singers of All Time]]. The following year, the [[Library of Congress]] selected his recording of "Amor eterno" for preservation in the United States [[National Recording Registry]].
